awd_titl_txt: Spatial Patterning in the Progressing Tumor - The Role of Notch
awd_abstract_narration:
Cancer becomes deadly when tumor cells become motile and begin to spread throughout the patient's body.  To become motile, cells must undergo radical changes in their composition and behavior, the so-called epithelial-mesenchymal transformation (EMT).  These radical changes arise as the network of genes controlling the state of the cell transitions from one type of stable fate to another. This project details a joint theory-experiment physics-biology effort to study how EMT is coordinated in space and time by chemical signals passed among the tumor cells.  The specific focus here is on the Notch signaling pathway. This pathway has been studied extensively for its role in developmental biology and has been implicated indirectly in cancer, but has never been studied systematically in this context. The hypothesis to be investigated is that this pathway can allow the formation of small clusters of cells that have undergone EMT together, and which thereafter travel as a collective en route to the establishment of a secondary tumor. If proven to be true, these ideas will shed light on the fundamental origins of metastasis and might in the future offer new strategies for both prognosis and treatment.
 
Cell-cell interactions, both between tumor cells proper and between tumor and stromal cells, are known to be a key component of many solid tumors. The investigators will focus on how one of these interactions, that mediated by the Notch pathway, can coordinate cell phenotypes and can thereby control tumor progression. To accomplish this will require the use and extension of sophisticated theory techniques from the field of non-equilibrium pattern formation coupled to an experimental plan focused on pancreatic cancer cell lines to be studied in both 2d and 3d in vitro conditions, both without and with supporting cancer-associated fibroblasts. Of particular importance will be measuring spatial correlations of EMT state (and other known correlates) and comparing these to expectations based on different signaling assumptions. Iterating these experiments with increasingly realistic model-building and model-solving will allow for the creation of a quantitatively reliable picture for the collective behavior of the tumor, going well-beyond current individual cell approaches.

This project is cofunded by the Physics of Living Systems Program in the Physics Division and the Molecular and Cellular Biosciences Division at NSF.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The goals of this proposal were to use a combination of mathematical models and biology experiments to elucidate the role of the Notch signaling pathway in governing phenotypes of individual cancer cells. Experiments were carried out by the group of Sendurai Mani at the MD Anderson Cancer Center and the modeling by our group at Northeastern and Rice in collaboration with a group at Bar-Ilan University. Specific topics to be addressed included: the coupling between cells via Notch and the epithelial-mesenchymal transformation (EMT); the role of different communication modes in cell patterning in the tumor environment; the coupling between cell signaling (via Notch) and the actual motility behavior of cells when they move collectively.

Major progress was made addressing these goals. On the experimental side, a landmark paper was published in the Proceedings of the National Academy that analyzed single-cell transcription for cells undergoing EMT and used novel analysis techniques to identify the role of various pathways including discovering a major role for Notch. Additional experiments by the Mani have shown how Notch signals are essential for enabling cells that undergo EMT to pick up additional properties related to their ability to initiate new tumor growths during metastasis.

Another set of key results concerns the specific coupling between Notch (and related pathways) and its induction of EMT, and the actual motility patterns exhibited by cells. Here, models were formulated that could be favorably compared to experiments by a group at Penn State. The results demonstrated that the predicted variation in signaling levels as one moved away from the leading edge of an expanding tissue or tumor could account for spatial variations in cell motility behavior. 

Notch signaling is critical not just for tumor progression but also for normal developmental processes. One interesting aspect of this pathway is that there are number of different ligands that can bind to the Notch receptors, classifed as belonging either to the Delta or Jagged molecular types. In our most recent theoretical work, we showed how the disparate effects of these different ligands could constructively "interfere", producing more robust cellular patterns in a variety of developmental biology examples. 

Taken all together, this project showed how combining modern quantitative experiment wih advanced modeling ideas from the physical science and mathematics community, can lead to rapid advances in understanding the workings of complex biological systems. This research then has the added broader impact of showing how this interdisciplinary strategy can accelerate progress. Also, this project formed the training ground for a number of students and postdoctoral fellows to become successful practitioners. Also, a number of summer interns from underrepresented background were able to take part in this effort, through interaction with the Rice University Frontiers in Science outreach effort, 

 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2023
Modified by: Herbert Levine
